fields.descriptive_line: Linen damask napkin, Flemish, 1550-1600, edged with 17th century needle lace
fields.physical_description:
Linen damask napkin, edged with needle lace.
The damask is a 4&1 satin, in a pattern of floral forms and pomegranates within scrolls. There are two pattern repeats in the width, three in the length. No border pattern. Three sides are decorated with a tiny line of pulled thread, started and unfinished on the fourth. To each end is attached a scalloped border of needle lace of later date, probably 1630s.

There is an embroidered mark, C M I * [?], worked in cross stitch in light brown silk, in one corner of the napkin.

The pattern is comparable to the silk damask 906-1899.
fields.dimensions: Length: 124 cm whole including lace, Length: 107 cm without lace, Width: 68 cm
fields.materials_techniques: Linen damask edged with needle lace
fields.public_access_description: In the early sixteenth century, damask table linen was still reserved for royalty, the church, and nobility. As the century progressed, linen damask weaving developed into an important branch of the textile industry, with its main centres in Flanders in the Southern Netherlands and Haarlem in Holland, and the use of table linen by merchants, trades people and others belonging to the middle and upper classes grew. By 1600, most of these households had at least one complete set of table linen, including one or more table cloths, and a number of napkins. Napkins were subject to official regulations that specified certain widths, and were either woven with borders all around or made from lengths of fabric and cut  to the required size, as this one has been.
fields.bibliography: D. M. Mitchell, ''By your Leave my Masters': British Taste in Table Linen in the Fifteenth and Sixteenth Centuries', Textile History 20.1 (1989), 49-77 Mitchell cites this object on p.57, note 59 to support his argument that table linen moves with a household.
fields.history_note:
This linen napkin has been edged with needle lace, which is later in date than the damask. It may have been passed to the church for ecclesiastical use, as it was not typical to decorate napkins with needle lace in this way for use at the dining table, although it did occasionally happen. The needle lace is of a type often considered English, but there is no English association with the provenance of this piece, which is likely to have come from a continental ecclesiastical source, since it is from the Bock collection.

Historical significance: The design of this linen damask relates closely to fashionable woven silks from the second half of the sixteenth century, for example 906-1899 in the museum's collection, a red silk damask. Before the seventeenth century, there was not a distinction in pattern between dress and furnishing silks (although  scale might dictate this, if a pattern repeat was exceptionally long) and this pomegranate pattern would have been suitable for a variety of purposes, including men's and women's dress, and table linen. 
Although linen damask from the sixteenth century is frequently recorded in inventories, its survival is relatively rare, largely because of  its suitablilty for re-use over long periods, until it was worn out, and the need, by its nature, to launder it frequently.
fields.historical_context_note:
At the beginning of the sixteenth century, damask table linen, characterised by its elaborate reversible patterns, was still reserved for royalty, the church, high nobility and the very rich among the bourgeoisie. As the century progressed, linen damask weaving developed into an important branch of the textile industry, with its main centres in Flanders in the Southern Netherlands and Haarlem in Holland, and the use of table linen by merchants, trades people and others belonging to the middle and upper classes grew. By 1600, most of these households had at least one complete set of table linen, including one or more table cloths, and a number of napkins. Napkins were subject to statutes that specified certain widths, and were either woven with borders all around or made from piece goods and cut  to the required length, as this one has been. 
(ref : C A Burgers, Some notes on Western European Table Linen from the 16th to the 18th centuries, in Upholstery in America and Europe from the Seventeenth Century to World War I, ed. E S Cooke, 1987)
